choices.B: Part II describes the definitions of terms used and the changes between versions of TOGAF
choices.C: Part III describes requirements management and is considered to be the core of TOGAF
choices.D: Part IV describes the ADM: a collection of guidelines and techniques used in TOGAF 9
choices.A: Part I describes the TOGAF approach to Enterprise Architecture

questions.question_text: Which one of the following statements about the structure of the TOGAF 9 document is true?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Correct answer then
The correct answer is D. Part IV describes the ADM: a collection of guidelines and techniques used in TOGAF 9.

Option A is the correct answer.

PART I
(Introduction) This part provides a high-level introduction to the key concepts of Enterprise Architecture and in particular the TOGAF approach. It contains the definitions of terms used throughout this standard.

https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf9-doc/arch/
BDAT is the architecture domain of enterprise architecture and for that reason, option A is the correct one.
A appears to be the correct answer

Selected Answer: A
A is the right answer

Selected Answer: A
Part 1 is the introduction. A high-level introduction to the key concepts of the Enterprise Architecture and in particular the TOGAF approach. It contains the definitions of terms used throughout the standard.
I think A is the one

Selected Answer: A
The Standards Information Base captures the standards with which new architectures must comply

comments.content:
The Standards Information Base provides a repository area to hold a set of speciﬁcations, to
which architectures must conform.

questions.question_text: What part of the Architecture Repository holds specifications toWhich architectures must conform?

discussion.content:
■ The Business Architecture of the architecture practice that will highlight the Architecture
Governance, architecture processes, architecture organizational structure, architecture
information requirements, architecture products, etc.
■ The Data Architecture that would define the structure of the organization’s Enterprise
Continuum and Architecture Repository
■ The Application Architecture specifying the functionality and/or applications services
required to enable the architecture practice
■ The Technology Architecture that depicts the architecture practice’s infrastructure
requirements and deployment in support of the architecture applications and Enterprise
Continuum

Part VI: Architecture Capability Framework 40.1 The Business Architecture of the architecture practice that will highlight the Architecture Governance, architecture processes, architecture organizational structure, architecture information requirements, architecture products, etc.

questions.question_text: TOGAF Part VII, Architecture Capability Framework recommends use of an ADM cycle for establishing an architecture practice. In this scenario which architecture would describe the organizational structure for the architecture practice?

choices.C: To help identify and understand requirements
choices.D: To highlight shortfalls between the baseline and target architectures
choices.A: To catch errors in a project architecture early
choices.E: To mitigate risk when implementing an architecture project
choices.B: To guide decision making throughout the enterprise

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes a purpose of the Business Scenarios technique?

discussion.content:
https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf9-doc/arch/chap06.html

6.3.8 Develop Architecture Vision
Business scenarios are an appropriate and useful technique to discover and document business requirements, and to articulate an Architecture Vision that responds to those requirements. Business scenarios may also be used at more detailed levels of the architecture work (e.g., in Phase B) and are described in the TOGAF® Series Guide: Business Scenarios.

26.6 Business Scenarios and the TOGAF ADM
Business scenarios figure most prominently in the initial phase of the Architecture Development Method (ADM), Architecture Vision, when they are used to define relevant business requirements, and to build consensus with business management and other stakeholders.

questions.question_text: Complete the sentence. The Requirements Management process is used to______.

discussion.content:
https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf9-doc/arch/chap16.html.
The objectives of the Requirements Management phase are to:

1. Ensure that the Requirements Management process is sustained and operates for all relevant ADM phases.
2. Manage architecture requirements identified during any execution of the ADM cycle or a phase.
3. Ensure that relevant architecture requirements are available for use by each phase as the phase is executed.

16.5.1 General
It is important to note that the Requirements Management circle denotes not a static set of requirements, but a dynamic process whereby requirements for Enterprise Architecture and subsequent changes to those "requirements are identified, stored, and fed into and out of the relevant ADM phases, and also between cycles of the ADM".

choices.C: organize architecture requirements throughout the ADM cycle
choices.A: develop requirements for Transition Architectures that deliver business value
choices.B: dispose of, address and prioritize architecture requirements
